title: Bitfinex hacker, rapper wife plead guilty in crypto heist money laundering
author: Sabrina Willmer
excerpt: One of the most enduring mysteries in the world of cryptocurrencies was resolved Thursday when Ilya Lichtenstein acknowledged that he was the hacker who executed the 2016 attack on the Bitfinex exchange. Lichtenstein, along with his social-media rapper wife, who...
summary:
One of the most enduring mysteries in the world of cryptocurrencies was resolved Thursday when Ilya Lichtenstein acknowledged that he was the hacker who executed the 2016 attack on the Bitfinex exchange.

Lichtenstein, along with his social-media rapper wife, who dubbed herself the 'Crocodile of Wall Street,' pleaded guilty to a money-laundering conspiracy tied to the theft of billions of dollars of Bitcoin from the exchange. Who executed the exploit has been the biggest guessing games in crypto after the identity of Bitcoin's pseudonymous creator, Satoshi Nakamoto.

author: Ari Redbord
excerpt: While the Senate debates and discusses AML for crypto, there is a lot legislators can learn from the recent pleas in the Bitfinex hack case.
summary:
The U.S. Senate passed the 2024 National Defense Authorization Act last Thursday, which included a provision that would require the U.S. Treasury Department and other regulators to create an examination and review process to ensure anti-money laundering compliance for crypto-related activities. The amendment also requires the Treasury to study and advise Congress on mixers and other anonymity-enhancing tools.

The NDAA provision, like a series of other AML-related proposals making their way through the halls of Congress, essentially tasks regulators with understanding and addressing the money laundering risks associated with crypto.
